channel.title: NYT > Climate and Environment
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Deadly Floods Devastate an Already Fragile Pakistan
item.description: More than 1,100 have died as record monsoon rains inundate the country, washing away bridges, roads and crop fields. Much of Pakistan is underwater.
item.dc:creator: Max Bearak, Raymond Zhong and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.media:description: Army troops evacuated people from a flood-hit area in Rajanpur, Punjab district, Pakistan, on Saturday.

item.title: Vancouver Moves to Sue Big Oil After Deadly Fires and Disastrous Floods
item.description: A potential lawsuit by Vancouver would be the first in Canada to target the fossil fuel industry’s role in climate change.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Melissa Renwick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scars left by a wildfire that destroyed the small town of Lytton, British Columbia.

item.title: Here Are the Challenges Ahead for California’s Ban on Gas Cars
item.description: Enforcement could be complex and legal challenges are likely. But ultimately, experts say, success or failure will depend on steady supply and buyers’ appetite.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: California’s policy will reverberate across the nation.

item.title: China’s Record Drought is Drying Rivers and Feeding Its Coal Habit
item.description: Dry weather in southwestern China has crippled huge hydroelectric dams, forcing cities to impose rolling blackouts and driving up the country’s use of coal.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher and Joy Dong
item.media:description: The dry riverbed of the Jialing River, a tributary of the Yangtze, last week in Chongqing in southwestern China.

item.title: As the Great Salt Lake Dries Up, Utah Faces An ‘Environmental Nuclear Bomb’
item.description: Climate change and rapid population growth are shrinking the lake, creating a bowl of toxic dust that could poison the air around Salt Lake City.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle and Bryan Tarnowski
item.media:credit: Bryan Tarnowski for The New York Times

item.title: The Science of Climate Change Explained: Facts, Evidence and Proof
item.description: Definitive answers to the big questions.
item.dc:creator: Julia Rosen
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

item.title: Heat, Water, Fire: How Climate Change Is Transforming the Pacific Crest Trail
item.description: The already grueling 2,600-mile hike now includes the added challenges of global warming, which can mean a lack of shade and exposure to smoke and fire.
item.dc:creator: Rowan Moore Gerety and Mason Trinca
item.media:description: Thru-hikers on the Pacific Crest Trail spend up to five months walking from Mexico to Canada — and the imprint of climate change is now felt along the entire route.

item.title: Gorbachev’s Op-Eds in The Times
item.description: Mikhail Gorbachev wrote often about issues ranging from world affairs to climate change. He also mourned former President Ronald Reagan and the former British prime minister, Margaret Thatcher.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: French Tax Collectors Use A.I. to Spot Thousands of Undeclared Pools
item.description: Algorithms combing through satellite photos found over 20,000 unreported swimming pools in a few regions, yielding an expected $10 million in taxes, and the system will soon go nationwide.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:credit: Francois Lo Presti/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Installing a swimming pool in northern France this month. The French government is using new technology to crack down on homeowners who fail to register pools to avoid higher property taxes.

item.title: First Solar says it will spend up to $1.2 billion to expand U.S. production.
item.description: The solar panel maker will build a factory in the Southeast and expand three Ohio plants, creating nearly 1,000 jobs.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: A First Solar factory in Perrysburg, Ohio. The solar panel manufacturer’s plans to expand its factories arrive on the heels of the Inflation Reduction Act.

item.title: After a Quiet August, Hurricane Forecasters Are Monitoring a Potential Storm
item.description: The disturbance could develop into a tropical storm in the next five days, after the first August in 25 years without a named storm in the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The five-day tropical weather outlook.

item.title: Why Pakistan Was Hit So Hard By Floods
item.description: Floods have killed at least 1,100 and submerged about a third of the country. We explain the factors making it so bad.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:description: Nowshera District, in northwestern Pakistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: This Remote Mine Could Foretell the Future of America’s Electric Car Industry
item.description: Hiding a thousand feet below the earth’s surface in this patch of northern Minnesota wetlands are ancient mineral deposits that some view as critical to fueling America’s clean energy future.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tim Gruber
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

item.title: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
item.description: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang and Kim Raff
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Ukraine launches a southern offensive.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian service members riding back from a position near the Kherson front line this month.

item.title: Greenland’s Melting Ice Sheet Could Raise Sea Levels by Nearly a Foot: Study
item.description: The study reached a more drastic conclusion than earlier assessments in part because it used a different method to gauge ice loss.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: An iceberg in Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland, in July.

item.title: Be ‘Less Squeamish’ About Drinking Recycled Wastewater, British Official Says
item.description: As droughts become more frequent, drinking water that has been reprocessed from sewage treatment is the future, the head of Britain’s Environment Agency said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A sewage treatment plant in Rickmansworth, England. Toilet-to-tap recycling is “perfectly safe and healthy, but not something many people fancy,” the head of Britain’s Environment Agency wrote this week.

item.title: Honda and LG will jointly build a U.S. battery plant.
item.description: The announcement comes as the auto industry ramps up its efforts to switch to electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:description: A Honda electric vehicle on display at the Central China Auto Show last month.

item.title: Low Water Levels Disrupt European River Cruises, a Favorite of U.S. Tourists
item.description: As the continent faces a severe drought, companies have had to use buses to transport passengers along parts of the Rhine and the Danube, where water levels have become too low for riverboats.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: A tourist vessel cruised in the partially dried up riverbed of the Rhine River in Bingen, Germany, in August.

item.title: Secret Data, Tiny Islands and a Quest for Treasure on the Ocean Floor
item.description: Mining in parts of the Pacific Ocean was meant to benefit poor countries, but an international agency gave a Canadian company access to prized seabed sites with metals crucial to the green energy revolution.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lipton
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: More attacks near a Ukrainian nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Central Mississippi Spared Feared Flooding From Heavy Rains, Officials Say
item.description: In Jackson, Miss., officials had warned that up to 150 homes could be affected and evacuations, but the Pearl River crested lower than expected on Monday morning, officials said.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin and Christine Hauser
item.media:description: An S.U.V. in floodwaters in this northeast neighborhood of Jackson, Miss., on Monday. Officials had recommended evacuations ahead of the weekend.

item.title: Biden’s Big Dreams Meet the Limits of ‘Imperfect’ Tools
item.description: The student loan plan is the latest example of Democrats practicing the art of the possible on the nation’s most pressing economic challenges and ending up with risky or patchwork solutions.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Cheriss May for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s plan to cancel some student loan debt could help millions of borrowers, but economists warn that it could also spur even faster tuition increases.

item.title: San Franciscans Are Done Apologizing for Their Cold Weather Summers
item.description: San Franciscans are done apologizing for their cold Julys and Augusts. In a time of punishing heat waves, the city likes being a place to chill out.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Fuller and Holly Secon
item.media:description: San Francisco’s summer fog and cool breezes are created by a complex interaction between the atmosphere and ocean.

item.title: E.P.A. to Designate PFAS, or ‘Forever Chemicals,’ as Hazardous
item.description: A proposed rule would require companies to report spills of two toxic chemicals that have been linked to cancer.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: PFAS chemicals have been found in a range of products including carpets, waterproof clothing and food packaging, including some microwave popcorn bags.

item.title: A smarter transition to electric vehicles
item.description: E.V.s will bring down emissions, but the materials needed to build them have other environmental costs. We explain why, and talk about ways to limit the harm.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni
item.media:credit: Marcos Zegers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lithium carbonate, used in batteries, at a processing plant in Antofagasta, Chile.

item.title: How to Plan a Sustainable Trip
item.description: Organizing a responsible visit to sensitive areas like the Galápagos Islands or Antarctica involves research, decoding certifications and possibly a travel adviser.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac

item.title: California E.V. Mandate Finds a Receptive Auto Industry
item.description: The move to phase out gasoline-powered cars, with other states expected to follow, matches automakers’ plans. The challenge will be making it happen.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A charging station in Burbank, Calif. Tesla has been a leader in the transition to electric vehicles, but established automakers are in hot pursuit.

item.title: Remains Found at Lake Mead Identified
item.description: Two decades ago, a man vanished in the water in front of his children. This week, their DNA samples helped to identify his remains, among several discovered recently amid a drought.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Joe Buglewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: A decomposing barrel along the shores of Lake Mead, near the spot where a victim who appeared to die from a gunshot wound was discovered in another barrel.

item.title: Hurricane Harvey Hit 5 Years Ago. Its Floodwaters Did Not Strike Equitably.
item.description: A new study on the catastrophic storm found that up to 50,000 homes would have been spared flooding from Harvey in a world without climate change.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:description: Floodwaters brought on by Hurricane Harvey in Houston overwhelmed the Addicks Reservoir in August 2017.

item.title: Can a Start-Up Help the Film and TV Industry Reduce Their Carbon Footprint?
item.description: The global entertainment industry generates millions of metric tons of carbon dioxide a year. A Spanish director has set up a company to try to cut that number substantially.
item.dc:creator: Farah Nayeri
item.media:credit: Charlotte Hadden for The New York Times
item.media:description: Eduardo Vieitez, a Spanish film and advertising director and the creator of the Creast app, which is designed to help productions reduce their carbon footprints.

item.title: Pace of Climate Change Sends Economists Back to Drawing Board
item.description: They underestimated the impact of global warming, and their preferred policy solution floundered in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.category: Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs

item.title: As France Swelters, Private Jets Come Under Attack
item.description: Politicians are proposing regulating or banning flights by such planes after a summer of extreme heat and soaring energy prices prompted growing calls to tackle the causes of climate change.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut

item.title: Covering a Disaster That Hasn’t Happened Yet
item.description: Giant rainstorms have ravaged California before. Times journalists combined data, graphics and old-fashioned reporting to explore what the next big one might look like.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: Rudy Mussi, a farmer in the Sacramento-San Joaquin Delta of California, has lived through two devastating levee failures near his land. Neither experience made him want to go farm somewhere else.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Six Months of War in Ukraine
item.description: Plus the future of milk in India and South Korea’s declining fertility rate.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik and Whet Moser
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian servicemen walking through a school bombed by Russian forces in Mykolaiv region this month.

item.title: California to Ban the Sale of New Gasoline Cars
item.description: The decision, to take effect by 2035, will very likely speed a wider transition to electric vehicles because many other states follow California’s standards.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport, Lisa Friedman and Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge. At least 12 other states are already in line to adopt California’s zero-emissions vehicle mandate.

item.title: India, a Dairy Titan, Studies How to Keep Milk Flowing in a Hotter World
item.description: As rising prices draw headlines, Indian scientists are getting creative in an effort to help producers, and animals, adapt.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cows at the National Dairy Research Institute in Karnal, India, where scientists study the impact of climate change on milk production.

item.title: Europe’s Drought Reveals WWII Relics and Bombs in Danube River
item.description: The Danube River is running so low on water that the wreckage of German warships, sunk in 1944, has resurfaced, posing a danger to local ship traffic.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Wreckage of a World War II German warship in the Danube in Prahovo, Serbia.

item.title: Hungary Fires Its Top Weather Officials After an Inaccurate Forecast
item.description: The National Meteorological Service predicted a severe storm over the weekend, prompting the government to postpone fireworks planned for a national holiday. The weather ended up being calm.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The colors of the Hungarian flag illuminated the Parliament building in Budapest to mark the national holiday. The skies were clear.

item.title: What Is Greenwashing and How Do You Avoid It?
item.description: It’s hard to see through misleading claims, even for those who care about the environment. Be very skeptical.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta

item.title: The Future of California’s Last Nuclear Power Plant
item.description: Advocates pushing to extend the life of the Diablo Canyon nuclear reactor are growing increasingly optimistic, despite critics’ concerns.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:description: The Diablo Canyon Power Plant in Avila Beach supplies about 9 percent of California’s electricity.

item.title: It’s Never Too Late to Become an Activist
item.description: Thirteen years ago, Bonnie McKinlay, a former schoolteacher, retired and embraced another passion: climate activism. She’s been arrested four times, but says it’s worth it.
item.dc:creator: Alix Strauss
item.media:credit: Kristina Barker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bonnie McKinlay, 72, at her home in Portland, Ore. Over the past 13 years, Ms. McKinlay has attended rallies, marches, hearings and protests at over 500 events.

item.title: How to Prepare Your Home for Severe Storms and Weather
item.description: With the cost and frequency of weather-driven disasters on the rise, taking steps to be ready is more crucial than ever.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard

item.title: Meeting Emissions Mandates in New York’s Buildings, Explained
item.description: Building owners are scrambling to meet new rules on greenhouse gas emissions. New York’s congressional candidates do the last-minute primary shuffle.
item.dc:creator: James Barron

item.title: Democrats Designed the Climate Law to Be a Game Changer. Here’s How.
item.description: In a first, the measure legally defines greenhouse gases as pollution. That’ll make new regulations much tougher to challenge in court.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Anna Rose Layden for The New York Times
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, seated, and supporters celebrated the passage of climate legislation.

item.title: U.N. Faces Record Humanitarian Aid Shortfall — but Not for Ukrainians
item.description: Soaring needs and wealthy countries’ focus on Ukraine have left aid agencies with too little money to address the world’s other crises, forcing them to cut programs.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Refugees from the Democratic Republic of Congo receiving lunch at a U.N. reception center in Kisoro, Uganda, in June.

item.title: Is Renting My Clothes Really the Most Sustainable Shopping Option?
item.description: A young professional concerned about climate change is looking for a wardrobe upgrade.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman

item.title: Expansion of Clean Energy Loans Is ‘Sleeping Giant’ of Climate Bill
item.description: The bill President Biden signed into law recently will greatly expand government loans and loan guarantees for clean energy and automotive projects and businesses.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: The John Day Dam, a hydropower dam in Washington State. New loan money could spur development of clean energy sources, like converting dams into power facilities.

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Can Planting a Trillion New Trees Save the World?’
item.description: To fight climate change, companies and nonprofits have been promoting worldwide planting campaigns. Getting to a trillion is easier said than done.
item.dc:creator: Zach St. George, Jack D’Isidoro, Aaron Esposito, John Woo, Dan Farrell and Quinton Kamara
item.media:credit: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times
item.media:description: Villagers hired by Eden Reforestation Projects planting trees in the northern part of Goiás State, Brazil.

item.title: Parts of Mexico and Texas Are Under a Tropical Storm Warning
item.description: Forecasters said a short-lived tropical storm could form and bring rain and storm surges.
item.dc:creator: McKenna Oxenden
item.media:description: The National Hurricane Center said on Saturday that a disturbance in the Gulf of Mexico had a 50 percent chance of becoming a tropical storm in the next 48 hours.

item.title: Dairy Farmers in the Netherlands Are Up in Arms Over Emission Cuts
item.description: Goals of cutting nitrogen emissions in half by 2030 have caused an uproar in the Netherlands. Climate activists say the cuts are necessary to preserve nature.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: “My livelihood and my network is being threatened,” said Ben Apeldoorn, who has been farming for 30 years.

item.title: UPS Drivers Say ‘Brutal’ Heat Is Endangering Their Lives
item.description: As summers have grown hotter, high temperatures inside trucks without air conditioning have also sickened postal carriers and others who deliver America’s packages. A few have died.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Matt Leichenger, 26, a driver with UPS, delivering packages along his route in Brooklyn Tuesday.

item.title: As Alaska Warms, Fires Burn Over (and Under) More Wild Land
item.description: Lightning storms, drought and thawing tundra are making fires more destructive. In the vast wilderness, firefighting is a major challenge.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Ash Adams for The New York Times
item.media:description: A firefighting crew from Fairbanks felt the ground for hot spots in the aftermath of the Clear fire.

item.title: Florida Utility Is Fined $500,000 for 2017 Explosion That Killed 5
item.description: Tampa Electric Company pleaded guilty in May to “willfully” violating an OSHA rule that required workers to receive a pre-job briefing about the work they were to perform.
item.dc:creator: Vimal Patel
item.media:credit: Zack Wittman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Big Bend Station in Apollo Beach, Fla.

item.title: Biden Prepares Actions to Cut Emissions After Signing Climate Bill
item.description: Regulations from the E.P.A. and elsewhere will help the president meet his aggressive climate goals, administration officials say.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Jim Tankersley
item.media:description: President Biden may deploy a series of regulatory measures, including new regulations on emissions from a variety of industries, even after signing the Inflation Reduction Act.
